title: 103_hr2632
content: The "Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 1993" authorizes $103,000,000 for the Patent and Trademark Office for fiscal year 1994. Fees collected under title 35, United States Code, and the Trademark Act of 1946 will also be available for the office's use. Amounts appropriated under this Act can remain available until expended. Adjustments to trademark fees are also authorized. SEC. 3. Amounts appropriated under this Act may remain available until expended. SEC. 4. Adjustments to trademark fees are authorized, with the fee for filing a trademark registration application set at $245. Any fee adjustments cannot take effect before October 1, 1994. SEC. 5. Interim patent extensions are addressed. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, allows for interim patent extensions if the regulatory review period extends beyond the patent term. The owner or agent can apply for an extension 6 months before the term expires, providing specific information about the product and patent. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code allows for interim patent extensions if the regulatory review period extends beyond the patent term. The applicant must provide specific information about the patent, product under review, activities undertaken during the review period, and any additional information required by the Commissioner. If the Commissioner determines eligibility for an extension, a notice will be published in the Federal Register, and a certificate of interim extension will be issued to the applicant. The owner of a patent can apply for up to 4 subsequent interim extensions, with exceptions for certain patents. Each extension must be applied for within a specific timeframe before the expiration of the previous extension. The certificate of interim extension is considered part of the original patent and is recorded in the patent file. Any interim extension granted will end 60 days after the product receives permission for commercial marketing or use. The patent can be further extended for up to 5 years if the product receives commercial marketing permission within 60 days. During the extension period, the patent rights are limited to the specific use under regulatory review. The patent rights are limited to the specific use claimed by the patent under regulatory review, including the method of manufacturing the product. SEC. 6. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to update subsections (a), (b), and (e) regarding patent rights. SEC. 7. PATENT TERM EXTENSIONS FOR AMERICAN LEGION. SEC. 7. Patent term extensions for American Legion: Design patents for the badges of the American Legion, American Legion Women's Auxiliary, and Sons of the American Legion are renewed and extended for 14 years from the date of enactment. SEC. 8. INTERVENING RIGHTS. The renewals and extensions of patents under section 6 will not result in infringement for any use of the patent's subject matter that began after the patent expired but before the enactment of this Act.
